posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Hello

I am looking for an example of a WPILib SwerveControllerCommand following a trajectory with a CTRE Swerve Project-generated CommandSwerveDrivetrain

It’s admittedly not a super useful use-case, but it is super easy to implement with code following the MAXSwerve template and less so with the CTRE template, and is quite nice to have to debug issues without introducing a third-party planning library in the mix…

Thanks!

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
We generally advise against using SwerveControllerCommand , as it is not well-maintained; it doesn’t discretize the applied ChassisSpeeds, for example. The SwerveControllerCommand outputting module states instead of a ChassisSpeeds can also impact performance; most of our swerve requests instead offload that to the C++ layer to avoid GC overhead.

Instead, the command can be easily reimplemented as a factory method in your CommandSwerveDrivetrain:

This also makes it easy to make improvements to the command. For example, you can swap out the HolonomicDriveController with an implementation that returns the field-centric ChassisSpeeds (without converting them to robot-centric speeds) and use our ApplyFieldSpeeds request, which can do the field-centric conversion at 250 Hz and automatically handles the discretization:

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Also the WPILib Trajectory class is meant for differential drive, and the accompanying TrajectoryGenerator doesn’t let the robot heading be separate from the velocity vector.

IMO the MaxSwerve example using the WPILib Trajectory puts users onto a limiting path.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Great! Thank you very much for such a quick and well-written reply. We will look into following your suggestion.

In case you are wondering, the background behind the question was that at 2495 we have quite successfully relied on that command in the past (using a Frankestein drivetrain with MK4i modules and Neos due to supply chain constraints). This season, we tried PathPlanner with the same drivetrain and we were not as successful, so we decided to go 100% CTRE going forward. We really like the SwerveGenerator but encountered more difficulties than we expected porting our existing code base to the CTRE generated code…

Thanks again.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thanks! Indeed, the WPILib Trajectory framework is not ideal for swerve drives, but it has the advantage of being officially supported and very well documented, which is convenient for a team with limited resources.

Lately we are only using it as some kind of reliable debugging/bringup tool. The question was somewhat academic.

Thinking back, a reason we kept using it is that we were somewhat expecting that Choreo could dethrone PathPlanner and wanted to wait for the dust to settle before picking a third-party framework…

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: Quick note if anyone happens to follow the example given in the second code block, you’ll need to invoke enableContinuousInput on m_holonomicThetaController

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Good catch! I’ve updated the code block to include that call.
